intro: Schoenoxiphium laxum, commonly known as the narrowleaf false foxglove, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Scrophulariaceae and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of tubular, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and woodland edges. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
